DM [BN] BOT 13-02-2023 19:08
You're in Vallaki and happen to near the Town Square. You hear the loud clang of a hand-bell. You see a stout, portly man with a blue coat and pale trousers flanked by a lanky teenage boy staring into space. They both stand on a small platform at the center of town. Townsfolk immediately stop what they are doing and a surprisingly large crowd quickly gathers. The man begins: "Oyez, Oyez, Oyez! The following is a decree from the most distinguished and generous Baron Vargas Vallakovich, to which The Burgomaster makes it known that the following persons are to report to his residence as soon is possible." The man elbows the teenager standing next to him. The teenager opens a scroll and recites in a flat, bored voice, "Autumn Whitlaw-Grimore, Everlen Sylvyre, Azrielia Lockstone, Rust (no surname), and Nora Havenwood." The crier continues, "These persons are suspected not of being charlatans, burglars, vagabonds, or instigators. You are to draw no conclusions." By now you are sure that the entire town is staring at you. It certainly feels that way. "Also, let it be known that... Oleg, it s your turn to light village lamps tonight." A single, disembodied groan rises from the back of the crowd, oozing with disappointment. "That is all!" The crier and teenager quickly turn and depart. @BN's Players

DM [BN] BOT 14-02-2023 14:31
The afternoon is slowly turning to night as the ever-present fog of Barovia starts to thicken, rolling in from Lake Zarovich. You make your way to the baron's manor. The home is quite large compared to the other homes within the village and leaves little doubt of who controls the purse strings. In front of the house on the road there is an elegant vardo, (a round-topped wagon, commonly used by the Vistani), adorned with bright colors and images of red roses. As your motley bunch approaches the door, you are welcomed into the home by a stoic servant that leads them into the abode. The servant does not engage in conversation. Inside the manor, the furniture is adorned with many flourishes and rich with deep, vibrant colors on the upholstery. The faint scent of spices and well-oiled leather fills the air. A large round table covered in a black velvet cloth dominates the parlor. At the far end sits a comely middle-aged woman dressed in bright colors. As you enter, she pulls a deck of lacquered cards from her gown and, spreading them in a graceful flourish, bids you to sit. Behind her, a rotund man in fine clothing stares out the window impatiently chewing on his thumbnail. Next to him, a woman, stern, face set in a permanent scowl.
